events.name: Charlotte Android Developers Monthly Meetup
events.description:
This event will give the Android developers and introduction to two interesting topics. The first talk will cover Netflixs RXJava library and how it can be used to help architect Android applications. The second talk will cover strategies for localization of Android applications, including tips and tricks to save you a lot of heartache.

Agenda:

6:30 Check in and Networking (Pizza)

7:00 RXJava Talk by Mike Drabic

7:30 Localization by Trey Robinson

8:00 Q&A

8:30 Wrap up

Speakers:

Mike Drabic

@MikeDrabic

Mike is a Senior Software Engineer at Skookum.

Trey Robinson

@rdrobinson3

Website

Trey is a Senior Software Engineer at Skookum. He is experienced in designing and developing enterprise mobile applications in iOS and Android.
events.how_to_find_us: From the lobby, take the elevator to the 15th floor. Someone will be there to greet you.

events.name: Charlotte Android Developers Monthly Meetup
events.description:
We have two new speakers and two awesome topics this month. One of the most common things done when writing mobile applications is accessing RESTful web-services. This normally requires a lot of boilerplate code, but it doesnt have to. Retrofit from Square is an Android networking library that takes a lot of pain out of networking code. During the talk well examine Retrofit in-depth and discuss its benefits. Well also discuss areas it could improve.

Continuous integration is vital to creating and testing reliable applications. Antoine Campbell will demonstrate an end to end build server using Jenkins. Builds include traditional unit test, user interface integration tests with Espresso, and code metrics with Sonar.

Agenda:

6:30 Check in and Networking (Pizza)

7:00 Retrofit by Chris Ollenburg

7:30 The Build Server Google Promised by Antoine Campbell

8:00 Q&A

8:30 Wrap up

Speakers:


Chris Ollenburg

@collenburg

<a>Linkedin</a>:

Taggd

Chris Ollenburg is an Android and iOS developer at Cardinal Solutions Group. Before Cardinal he was the Lead Android Developer at Lowes Home Improvement. Chris is also working on a street art related startup, Taggd.

Antoine Campbell

I am a Charlotte based consultant. Working primarily on web services and mobile applications. I have experience with iOS and Android. I'm also a First Robotics mentor.

Title: Senior Consultant
events.how_to_find_us: From the lobby, take the elevator to the 15th floor. Someone will be there to greet you.

events.name: Charlotte Android Developers Monthly Meetup
events.description:
This month Seth Clark from Bank Of America will be talking about View performance optimization.

The second talk by John Hiott will cover Location Services. Knowing your users location can help provide a better user experience. However, there are a few things to consider when developing your application. You need to to consider the movement of the user, the accuracy of the location provided, the source of the location, and battery life. During the talk John Hiott will discuss the different methods and their pros and cons.

Both guys will be passing along real world tips and tricks that you can start using to enhance your applications.

Agenda:

6:30 Check in and Networking (Pizza)

7:00 Reusable View Creation Tips/Tricks by Seth Clark

7:30 Location Services by John Hiott

8:00 Q&A

8:30 Wrap up

Speakers:

https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/2073653?v=3&s=460

Seth Clark

Seth Clark has been an Android developer at Bank of America for the past 3 years. Before that he was working on my graduate degree virtual reality and game design at the University of North Carolina - Charlotte.

https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/1245821?v=3&s=400

John Hiott

@johnhiott

Developer @ Passport

John Hiott is full stack developer focusing on Android at Passport in Charlotte, North Carolina.
At Passport, John works on their parking enforcement mobile application.
events.how_to_find_us: From the lobby, take the elevator to the 15th floor. Someone will be there to greet you.

events.name: Charlotte Android Developers Monthly Meetup
events.description:
This week Antoine Campbell returns to talk give an introduction into the world of Android Testing; Instrumentation, Unit, Espresso, Robotium, Robolectric, Android Mock. He will offer an in-depth look at the arsenal available to Android developers to test their app before it reaches a tester's hands.

Todd Evans will show how Android newcomers, regardless of programming background, can get jump started writing Android apps with a live demonstration of popular rapid application development tool B4A (formerly Basic4Android).

http://www.b4x.com/index.html

Agenda:

6:30 Check in and Networking (Pizza)

7:00 Intro To Android Testing by Antoine Campbell

7:30 - B4A (Basic4Android) by Todd Evans

8:00 Q&A

8:30 Wrap up

Speakers:

Antoine Campbell

I am a Charlotte based consultant. Working primarily on web services and mobile applications. I have experience with iOS and Android. I'm also a First Robotics mentor.

Title: Senior Consultant

Todd Evans

Todd Evans is a Systems Engineer for Janam Technologies (Woodbury, NY), a manufacturer of ruggedized mobile computers and tablets running Android and Windows operating systems. He has held similar positions at Datalogic and PSC spanning more than 10 years.

While attending UNC-Charlotte in the early 1990's, he authored MachSIx, a query optimizer for dBase files and later sold to SuccessWare. Other notables include TelecomC - a custom C compiler and multi-tasking kernel optimized for telephony applications at WorldxChange Communications. And more recently co-architect and developer of Stay-Linked a connectionless Telnet service for 5250, 3270, and VT emulation resistant to network service disruptions common in warehouses and distribution centers.

http://www.staylinked.com/
events.how_to_find_us: From the lobby, take the elevator to the 15th floor. Someone will be there to greet you.

events.name: Charlotte Android Developers Monthly Meetup
events.description:
In the aftermath of Google I/O it is time to take a look at some of the sweet new Android APIs. This week we will feature our first ever set of Lightning Talks. We will take a quick look at some of the latest news from I/O with several 7-10 minutes talks. See the speaker lineup below! Many of the names should be familiar from our past meetings. Don't see the topic your are looking for? Let us know in the comments before next Tuesday and we will make sure to cover it.

Agenda:

6:30 Check in and Networking (Pizza)

6:45 Lightning Talks

8:00 Q&A

8:30 Wrap up

Speakers:

John Hiott - Design Support Library

Chris Ollenburg - App Linking

Seth Clark - Permissions

Trey Robinson - View Data Binding

Antoine Campbell - Voice Interactions
events.how_to_find_us: From the lobby, take the elevator to the 15th floor. Someone will be there to greet you.

events.name: Charlotte Android Developers Monthly Meetup - Android Wear
events.description:
This week our talk will be given be all about Getting Started with Android Wear!Android Wear presents a new opportunity for engaging with users. Ill start with some guidance for whether and why you would want to build an Android Wear app, then go through some of the unique design considerations for a watch, and finish up with some code samples to help get you started.

Agenda:

6:30 Check in and Networking (Pizza)

7:00 Android Wear by Jeb Ware

8:00 Q&A

8:30 Wrap up

Speakers:

Jeb Ware

Jebis an Android developer consultant who has been developing for Android since the original G1. His clients have included big names like Charles Schwab and American Express, as well as local startups like The Beer Exchange, MailVU, and Punch Technologies. He enjoys breaking a new phone every six months, trying out the shiny new APIs in each Android release, and long walks on the beach at sunset.

https://twitter.com/jebstuart
https://about.me/ware
events.how_to_find_us: From the lobby, take the elevator to the 15th floor. Someone will be there to greet you.

events.name: Charlotte Android Developers Monthly Meetup
events.description:
This month we return to our regular format. Our first talk will be by John Hiott on Stetho.Stetho is a powerful debug bridge for Android. Stetho allows developers to use the Chrome Developer tools to debug their application and provides a powerful CLI, dumpapp. The talk will cover how to integrate Stetho into your application, use the Chrome developer tools and demonstrate how to write a simple plugin dumpapp.

The second talk will be about tips and tricks to make you a more efficient Android developer. Whether you are a new developer or an experienced one, this talk will cover both popular and little known tips to improve and enhance your development experience.

Agenda:

6:30 Check in and Networking (Pizza)

7:00 Stetho by John Hiott

7:30 Android Developer Tips by Trey Robinson

8:00 Q&A

8:30 Wrap up

https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/1245821?v=3&s=400

John Hiott

@johnhiott

Trey Robinson

@rdrobinson3

Website

Trey is a Senior Software Engineer at Skookum. He is experienced in designing and developing enterprise mobile applications in iOS and Android.

events.description:

For our second talk Seth Clark returns to teach us all about developing VR experiences for Google Cardboard.

Agenda:

6:30 Check in and Networking (Pizza)

7:00 Java 8 w/ Harish

7:30 Google Cardboard w/ Seth Clark

8:00 Q&A

We will also discuss ideas for how the meetup can be improved in 2016. Please bring some great ideas!

Agenda:

6:30 Check in and Networking (Pizza)

7:00 Transitions w/ Chris Ollenburg

7:30 Ideas for 2016

8:00 Wrap up

events.name: Charlotte Android Developers Monthly Meetup
events.description:
This month Seth Clark will cover the new Finger Print API. Trey Robinson will cover the new vector graphic support in Android Studio.

Agenda:

6:30 Check in and Networking (Pizza)

7:00 Fingerprint Authentication w/ Seth Clark

events.how_to_find_us: From the lobby, take the elevator to the 15th floor. Someone will be there to greet you.

events.name: Charlotte Android Developers Monthly Meetup
events.description:
It is a new year and there are some big changes in store for the Android meetup. Last year we asked you what you wanted to see in 2016. This month we will outline the new structure for the meetup and start our year long journey to not only educating each other via technical talks but by actively implementing these techniques in a hands-on open source application.

We will be partnering with the Charlotte Google Developer Group and the iOS Meetup Group. This kickoff will be a joint meetup so come meet some folks from the other side of the mobile aisle.
events.how_to_find_us: From the lobby, take the elevator to the 15th floor. Someone will be there to greet you.

events.name: Charlotte Android Developers Monthly Meetup
events.description:
At our last meeting we announced an exciting new initiative for 2016. This year we will build an open source app together. The final details of what the project will be are still not finalized (soon I promise!)

This year we will continue to have a series of great talks but each talk will emphasize a piece of a larger community project.

This month we are starting off with some basics for those who are new to Android, Git, or contributing to open source. This months agenda includes:

Project Updates

Introduction to Git w/ John Hiott

Source Repositories, Team Communications, Timelines, and Contribution Guidelines

If you want help setting up and you want to try some of the things that will be discussed then BRING YOUR LAPTOP to this meeting. The agenda will start promptly at 7:00pm.

If you need help setting you your Android IDE, getting setup with Github or have any other technical questions then bring your computer and arrive closer to 6:30 and we will help you out.

Our goal is to make sure everyone that wants to participate is ready to do so. If you miss this month don't worry! Just come early next month and we can answer your questions.

Finally, If anyone has a side project they would like to show off then send me a message. I will reserve the first 10 minutes of each meeting for a demo. First come first serve.
events.how_to_find_us: From the lobby, take the elevator to the 15th floor. Someone will be there to greet you.

events.name: Charlotte Android Developers Monthly Meetup
events.description:
This months agenda includes:

Trail of History Project Updates

Building our first feature with Recycler View

The agenda will start promptly at7:00pm.

If you need help setting you your Android IDE, getting setup with Github or have any other technical questions then bring your computer and arrive closer to 6:30 and we will help you out.

Our goal is to make sure everyone that wants to participate is ready to do so. If you miss this month don't worry! Just come early next month and we can answer your questions.

Finally, If anyone has a side project they would like to show off then send me a message. I will reserve the first 10 minutes of each meeting for a demo. First come first serve.
events.how_to_find_us: From the lobby, take the elevator to the 15th floor. Someone will be there to greet you.

events.name: Walk the Trail of History
events.description:
We're going to walk the Trail of History this weekend to gather data and find out more about the project we're working on. Come out and get inspired to make this app awesome!

The plan is to meet in front of Hickory Tavern. The metropolitan has a huge parking garage where you can park for free. We'll meet at 9:30 am and then walk the trail of history. While the weather forecast has a high of 61, make sure you bring some water!

events.name: Charlotte Android Developers Monthly Meetup
events.description: Seth Clark will be speaking about Retrofit 2. We will also go over the latest details of the Trail of History project.
events.how_to_find_us: From the lobby, take the elevator to the 15th floor. Someone will be there to greet you.

events.name: Charlotte Android Developers Monthly Meetup
events.description:
Come out for a fun meetup! We'll have a quick update on the Trail of History project and then we've got a guest speaker.

Android Accessibility - Surprising Users of your Android Apps by Eliezer Rodriguez

Discover how small changes to your apps could greatly help improve the quality of life of an untapped user group in our population today. Hear some interesting facts I have learned about user accessibility, experience and the near future of mobile apps.
events.how_to_find_us: From the lobby, take the elevator to the 15th floor. Someone will be there to greet you.

events.name: Charlotte Android Developers Monthly Meetup
events.description:
Firebase!

Google showed off a lot of updates to Firebase at Google I/O. We will discuss what is new and show of a version of the Trail of History admin tool running on the platform.
events.how_to_find_us: From the lobby, take the elevator to the 15th floor. Someone will be there to greet you.

events.name: Google Hangout: Trail of History
events.description:
https://hangouts.google.com/call/nmw7w23idvbm5mdp4lzcos3kf4e

https://plus.google.com/events/cn3cndil7mch03gd4p2epvcpmrs

There are a lot of issues in the Trail of History application. This Hangout is for us to work through those issues together.

There is no set agenda and you can join and leave the call as you wish. Some items that will likely be covered include:

New feature development

Design Review

Pull Request review

Issue requirements

If you are working on one of the issues this is the time and place to discuss it with the entire group.
events.how_to_find_us: A hangout will be posted here and in the slack channel closer to the time of the event.

events.name: Charlotte Android Developers Monthly Meetup: Joint Meetup with iOS this month!
events.description:
This month we will be reviewing the Android and iOS designs for the trail of history application. Our designer Josh Abe will be walking through the designs and we will be taking feedback on ways they can be changed or improved.

If you are currently working on any open issues and you would like to discuss them we will do that following the design discussion.
events.how_to_find_us: From the lobby, take the elevator to the 15th floor. Someone will be there to greet you.

events.name: Submit your App with a new Print function for big prizes! Register at the link
events.description:
Mopria Alliance wants to reward you for working on your app. They have organized an Android Print Challenge for devs to work on their existing apps. Those that add Androids print API will be rewarded with prizes from a $10K Prizepool!

The Android print API allows users to print to printers on the cloud from their mobile device. Almost any app could use this function, from games to business apps, and it only requires about an hour of coding. Mopria Alliance will award you with an Amazon giftcard for submitting, and youll be eligible for huge prizes!

Compete for prizes while adding a great function to your app. Submit by Sept. 6th to be eligible for semi-final and grand prizes. But if you submit by Monday, Aug. 22nd, youll be competing for 2 prizes (Oculus Rift and Flatscreen TV), plus the grand prizes (3 winners, $2K each).

Register at the link and submit your app when youre ready: http://bit.ly/joinappsthatprint

events.name: Hangout: Trail Of History
events.description:
Live Coding. Chris Ollenburg will lead the group in the creation of the Trail Of History RecyclerReview.

Live on Air:https://plus.google.com/events/cq0ejemhu4bntjr0dtrq9q1umps?hl=en

events.name: Charlotte Android Developers Monthly Meetup
events.description:
Antoine Campbell of CapTech will be demonstrating how he got continuous integration setup for the Trail of History.

We will also review the Trail of History app development progress. If you are new to the meetup and are not yet involved in the open source app project do not worry! We will get you up to speed and find a way you can contribute (if desired).

Pull requests are always welcome. You can find more on the Trail of History project by visiting the repository: https://github.com/cltmobilemeetup/trail-of-history-android
events.how_to_find_us: From the lobby, take the elevator to the 15th floor. Someone will be there to greet you.

events.name: Charlotte Android Developers Monthly Meetup
events.description:
Hack Night!

Come help out with the trail of history project or bring your own project and get some help from the Charlotte Android developer community. We will start coding at 6:30 and sling some code until 8:30.
events.how_to_find_us: From the lobby, take the elevator to the 15th floor. Someone will be there to greet you.

events.name: Charlotte Android Developers Monthly Meetup
events.how_to_find_us: From the lobby, take the elevator to the 15th floor. Someone will be there to greet you.

events.name: Charlotte Android Developers Monthly Meetup
events.description:
Welcome back to a new year! Make sure you bring your laptops as we may have a working session tonight after the discussions. Looking forward to seeing everyone!

Agenda:

- Discuss last year

- Goals for this year

- Special surprise talk

- Working session - get help or help others with Android code (Time Allowing).
events.how_to_find_us: From the lobby, take the elevator to the 15th floor. Someone will be there to greet you.

events.name: Charlotte Android Developers Monthly Meetup
events.description:
Joins us for a talk from Jeb Ware onIntro to Android Security.

Lets explore the basics of secure application development on Android. Well cover the application sandboxing model and some practical implications (and pitfalls!), network connection security, and protections against reverse engineering with Proguard.

This talk is 100% demos (no slides!) Its aimed at newcomers to Android development, though even experienced Android devs should come away with something new that they havent seen before.

After Jeb's talk Seth Clark will present on Extending AutoValue.

events.name: Charlotte Android Developers Monthly Meetup
events.description:
This month, in our first talk, Seth Clark will be doing a high level recap of all of the exciting new features for Android announced at this year's Google IO event.

In the second talk Jeb Ware will show you how you can utilize your existing skills in Android development to target IoT with his introduction to Android Things.

Agenda:

6:30 Check in and Networking (Pizza)

6:45 IO Recap by Seth Clark

7:15 Introduction to Android Things by Jeb Ware

7:45 Q&A

8:00 Wrap up

Speakers:

Seth Clark

Seth has been developing applications and libraries professionally for Android for the past 6 years. Once a developer and Bank of America where he helped deliver Android products to over 20 million users, he now works for Salesforce on their Marketing Cloud SDK.

https://twitter.com/setheclark
https://github.com/setheclark

Jeb Ware

Jeb has been developing for Android since the original G1. He has worked at Lockheed Martin and Charles Schwab, and made apps for several local startups. He enjoys breaking a new phone every six months, trying out the shiny new APIs in each Android release, and long walks on the beach at sunset.

https://twitter.com/jebstuart
https://about.me/ware

events.name: Meetup Mashup Night - Presented by Skookum and Red Ventures
events.description:
Come out for Meetup Mashup Night! We'll be hosting a series of "lightning talks" on a variety of technical and design related topics from professionals working in the Charlotte area. We'll be joining with several other Meetup community members from a variety of groups here in Charlotte to learn about the larger technology community, and gain some knowledge outside of our regular format. Pizza and drinks will be provided as usual, but we'll get started just a bit earlier to accommodate all of the speakers. Specific speakers and topics will be announced as we get closer to time, but there definitely will be something for everyone. Here's what we have so-far:

Embracing Diversity in Everything We Do - Josh Miller (Skookum)

Peer Code Reviews: Eliminating the Gatekeeper - John Epperson (N2 Publishing)

Why Your Friend Should Come Work in Charlotte - Ted Prendergast (Red Ventures)

Jumping Into Open Source Waters - Joshua Lawson (Charlotte Jr. Devs)

Growth of the Progressive Volunteer Tech Community - Jacob LeGrone (Skookum)

Why Go? - Dimitrios Arethas (Red Ventures)

How Corporate Culture Impacts Design - Mike Sales (NASCAR Digital Media)

Closing the Gender Gap in Technology - Cristina Veale (Cardinal Solutions / Girl Develop It)

Picking Your Second Programming Language - Zack Kirchin (Tech Talent South)

TBD - Oliver Short (The Iron Yard)

TBD - Nick Breaton (Investor Management Services) Special thanks to our sponsors Skookum and Red Ventures for making this happen!

events.name: Monthly Developers Meetup - How Proguard Works
events.description:
Some Android devs treat ProGuard like a scary black box that breaks their app in inscrutable ways, and must be tamed with lots of -keep statements. Others give up and turn it off entirely. In this talk, I show how ProGuard is analyzing, and transforming your app. I show how it fits into the build process, how to successfully configure it, and how to use its outputs. I end with a preview of the changes coming with R8, which is planned to replace ProGuard in the Android build process.

Speaker: Jeb Ware
https://jebware.com/blog/
@jebstuart

Jeb Ware is a Senior Engineer in the Technology organization at American Express, where he works on Android applications. He has been developing for Android since the original G1. He enjoys breaking a new phone every six months, trying out the shiny new APIs in each Android release, and decompiling your app to see how it's working.

Agenda:
6:00 - Check in and networking (Food/Drink)
6:30 - How Proguard Works
7:30 - Q&A + More networking
8:00 - Wrap up

events.name: TensorFlow DevSummit Viewing Party
events.description:
What we'll do
TensorFlow Dev Summit brings together a diverse mix of machine learning users from around the world for a full day of highly technical talks, demos, and conversation with the TensorFlow team and community.

Come join us as we get together to watch some of the highlights from the event. There will be food and drink provided. We will also have a few things to give away to participants.

What to bring

Important to know
Parking: On-street metered parking is free after 6PM and is only $1/hour before 6. There is a lot of construction around the build so there might not be a ton of options for this. You can also park in the Weston Hotel Parking garage on the same property, but I'm unsure of the hourly rate of this option. Another option is to take the light rail to the Stonewall Station.
events.how_to_find_us: The WeWork office is the building on the left.  If the door is locked then please knock and the security guard will let you in.  Once in the building, take the elevator to the 9th floor.

events.name: Google IO Extended
events.description:
Join us as we recap the major updates and announcements from this year's Google IO event. We will have members of Charlotte's top technology talent presenting 10-15 minute lightning talks on some of the interesting announcements with time for discussion about what they mean for the Google technology community.

Tentative Agenda:
5:30 - 6: Socialize/Food
6 - 7:30: Lightning talks:
- What's new in Android (Jeb Ware)
- TensorFlow Lite for mobile developer (Antoine Campbell)
- Android Jetpack and Arch Components (Trey Robinson)
- What's new in Angular (Jocelyn Keung)
- Build great Material Design products across platforms (Steve Novack)
7:30 - 8: Discussion time

events.name: Build Actions for Your Community
events.description:
What we'll do
"Build Actions for Your Community" is a 1-day event for developers of all skill level to come together to learn how to create Actions for Google Assistant.

Schedule:
9:30am: Registration
10:00am: Introduction
10:10am: [TALK] - Building Conversational Experiences with Actions on Google
11:10am: Codelab: Build Actions for the Google Assistant (Level 1)
12:25pm: Lunch
1:00pm: Codelab: Build Actions for the Google Assistant (Level 2)
2:00pm: Create your Actions on Google
3:30pm: Feedback on the Actions on Google Platform
4:00pm: Demo your Actions

What to bring
Laptop

Important to know
This is a day-long event. While we will not restrict you from leaving early, it is best if you can stay for the entire event.

For this event we'll be using the entrance located on Louise Avenue. The event door is the grey door with a colorful Advent logo.

events.name: Fleurix Women's Tech Conference #IWD #WTM19
events.description:
We are excited to share with you Charlottes first conference for women in IT. Fleurix aims to connect women with an inspiring community and accessible resources to help conquer common barriers to entry, retention, and promotion of women in technology-related careers.

The conference will be held on March 29-30, 2019 at Camp North End and will include skills workshops, mentor sessions, dynamic networking activities, and panels, all led by impactful, local women in the field. For more information and how to register, visit www.fleurixconf.com and follow their Instagram (@fleurixconf) and Facebook (@fleurixconference).

The conference fee is $35 for two days and includes lunch and refreshments. Spots are limited, so register early. See you there!

#IWD19 #WomenTechmakers

events.name: SQLite:  What it is, where it came from, and where it is going
events.description:
The Charlotte GDG presents Dr. Richard Hipp, the creator of SQLite to share his talk:

SQLite: What it is, where it came from, and where it is going

Bio:
Charlotte-born D. Richard Hipp is the creator and lead developer for SQLite - the most used database engine in the world. After taking a Ph.D. from Duke University with a dissertation in AI in 1992, Richard started a small company that developed bespoke software for solving hard problems. That company later evolved into the team that now supports SQLite. Richard lives in the Highland Creek neighborhood in north Charlotte. He is a frequent invited speaker at workshops, conferences, and lectures around the world.

5:30 - 6:00 :: Food/Networking
6:00 - 7:00 :: Dr. Richard Hipp
events.how_to_find_us: Packard Place, 5th floor, Insight(formerly Cardinal Solutions)
